aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Collision at Helipad
The pilot of N911FA made a normal approach from the north to the main pad.
The pilot of N911FA performed a left pedal turn from the main pad.
The left pedal turn rotated the helicopter to the east.
The pilot of N911FA hover-taxied toward pad 2.
The pilot of N911FA made a right pedal turn.
The right pedal turn rotated the helicopter to the south.
The pilot of N911FA lowered the collective to land on pad 2.
N911FA's main rotor blades came into contact with N96BM's main rotor blades.
N96BM was positioned on Pad 1.
The air support Lieutenant was interviewed on November 18, 2012.
The air support Lieutenant observed spotty weather throughout the day prior to the accident.
The weather alternated between clear and cloudy/overcast.
The air support Lieutenant observed marginal weather conditions as N911FA took off.
The air support Lieutenant noted the weather was closing in a couple of minutes later.
The air support Lieutenant observed N96BM was on Pad 1 preparing to take off.
The air support Lieutenant walked out of his office toward N96BM.
The air support Lieutenant intended to tell the flight crew to stand down.
The air support Lieutenant was standing by the left door on the outside of N96BM.
The air support Lieutenant observed N911FA returning to base.
The air support Lieutenant thought N911FA's return was a good thing.
The air support Lieutenant recalled hearing a loud bang.
The air support Lieutenant was knocked to the ground.
The air support Lieutenant ran away from N96BM after being knocked down.

text:
The pilot of N911FA made a normal approach from the north to the main pad. From the main pad, the pilot performed a left pedal turn turning the helicopter to the east, and hover-taxied toward pad 2. The pilot then made a right pedal turn, turning the helicopter to the south. As she lowered the collective to land on pad 2, the main rotor blades came into contact with N96BM's main rotor blades.

The air support Lieutenant (Lt.) was interviewed on November 18, 2012. He had observed that throughout the day prior to the accident, the weather had been spotty; clear one moment, cloudy and overcast the next. As N911FA took off, he observed from his office marginal weather conditions. A couple of minutes later, he looked out his window, and noted that the weather was closing in, and that N96BM was on Pad 1 preparing to take off. He walked out of his office toward N96BM, with the intent of telling the flight crew to stand down. He stated that he had been standing by the left door on the outside of N96BM. He observed N911FA returning to base, and thought that was a good thing. He recalled hearing a loud bang, getting knocked to the ground, and then running away from N96BM.

## PERSONNEL INFORMATION
